sentences.english: With the formal suits but humorous gestures, the Chorale made their first appearance.
sentences.chinese: 正式的着装，诙谐的动作，是该合唱团的出场秀。

sentences.english: But I have tried comical and funny roles before.
sentences.chinese: 但我尝试过滑稽诙谐的角色。
我们都很欣赏他的“诙谐”。

sentences.english: They have just been pulling our legs very wittily.
sentences.chinese: 他们不过是跟我们开个非常诙谐的玩笑罢了。
他们俩都是幽默诙谐的人。

sentences.english: His new novel is tinged with thinnish humor.
The conversation on Thursday evening was light and jovial.
sentences.chinese: 周四晚上的这场对话显得既轻松且诙谐。

sentences.english: Chapter Three, the evaluation and succession for the humorous poetry style of Han Yu.
sentences.chinese: 第三章，后代对韩愈诙谐诗风的评价及继承。

sentences.english: In his hands, comic jargon and dialect became a finished literary weapon .
sentences.chinese: 在他的手里，诙谐的方言，俚语成了完美的文字武器。

sentences.english: The language with humorous is one of the seasons that the story attains success.
sentences.chinese: 幽默诙谐的语言是阿凡提故事成功的奥秘之一。

sentences.english: Some of the students commented humorously on their teacher's cap.
sentences.chinese: 有一些学生诙谐地议论他们老师的帽子。

sentences.english: At high school, mike's homespun humour was the cause of much laughter.
sentences.chinese: 高中时，迈克朴质的诙谐引起了良多笑声。

sentences.english: The funny cunning runner uses his gum gun when sunrise or after sunset.
sentences.chinese: 诙谐灵便的赛跑者在日出之前或日落之后使用胶皮枪。

sentences.english: He is such a jocose actor.
sentences.chinese: 他真是一位诙谐的演员。

sentences.english: Mr. A is a gleg man of a jocose nature.
sentences.chinese: 先生是一位天生诙谐而反应机敏的人。

sentences.english: It begs to be converted to witty signaturesat the bottom of emails.
sentences.chinese: 它渴望被转换成邮件底部的诙谐签名。

definition: to amuse/to make sb laugh/to tease
silly talk or "mo lei tau" (Cantonese), genre of humor emerging from Hong Kong late in the 20th century
lit. laughs, jeers, anger and invective (idiom)/fig. all kinds of emotions/to mock and scold/(of writing) freely roving/following the author's fancy
uproarious/hilarious/to split one's sides laughing/lit. to hold one's belly with both hands
comical/funny/amusing/old pr. [gu3 ji1]/huaji, a form of comedy performance popular in Shanghai, Jiangsu and Zhejiang
to include impromptu comic material in opera performance (idiom); to jest/buffoonery
